title: Reply to: Weather anomalies cannot explain insect decline
author: Jörg Müller
excerpt: Nature - Reply to: Weather anomalies cannot explain insect decline
text: Matters Arising Published: 12 March 2025 Nature volume 639, pages E12–E13 (2025)Cite this article Subjects replying to: C. A. Hallmann et al. Nature https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-024-08528-0 (2025).We very much appreciate that our article1 has stimulated discussions on potential reasons for temporal variations in insect biomass. In the accompanying Comment2, Hallmann et al. further contribute to this scientific discourse by posing questions regarding the analyses and the validation data presented in our work. It is generally considered best scientific practice to first replicate a previous approach as a reference and then add extensions and corrections with new data and ideas to facilitate the comparison, as we did in response to the original work by Hallmann and colleagues3. Unfortunately, the authors did not seize the opportunity to utilize our published model, a key component of our study, for testing the contribution of weather to the variation in their newly presented data4,5. • Matters Arising
  • Published: 12 March 2025

Nature volume 639, pages E12–E13 (2025)Cite this article

Subjects

replying to: C. A. Hallmann et al. Nature https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-024-08528-0 (2025).

We very much appreciate that our article1 has stimulated discussions on potential reasons for temporal variations in insect biomass. In the accompanying Comment2, Hallmann et al. further contribute to this scientific discourse by posing questions regarding the analyses and the validation data presented in our work. It is generally considered best scientific practice to first replicate a previous approach as a reference and then add extensions and corrections with new data and ideas to facilitate the comparison, as we did in response to the original work by Hallmann and colleagues3. Unfortunately, the authors did not seize the opportunity to utilize our published model, a key component of our study, for testing the contribution of weather to the variation in their newly presented data4,5.
